text:
the problem you're facing in gnuplot is that the build system wants to run a binary executable, `lrelease`.  there are some issues:

1. I have no idea what it's supposed to do
2. we don't have it
3. it's a binary executable.  we can't run foreign executables.  trying to build a JLL package for qttools is totally useless for your purpose, that's not what we need

elements.text: the problem you're facing in gnuplot is that the build system wants to run a binary executable,
lrelease

.  there are some issues:

1. I have no idea what it's supposed to do
2. we don't have it
3. it's a binary executable.  we can't run foreign executables.  trying to build a JLL package for qttools is totally useless for your purpose, that's not what we need

text: I'd start from the first point, answering the question: what does `lrelease` do?

elements.text: I'd start from the first point, answering the question: what does
lrelease
do?

text: to build packages you need to _understand_ the build system, what it tries to do

elements.text: to build packages you need to
understand
the build system, what it tries to do

text: Hmmm... I thought it was just a binary provided by qttools.... and required by gnuplot....

elements.text: Hmmm... I thought it was just a binary provided by qttools.... and required by gnuplot....

text: do you know what it does?  why is it required?  I don't know anything about it

elements.text: do you know what it does?  why is it required?  I don't know anything about it

text: also, many packages don't consider cross-compiling as an option, so you need to deal with it

elements.text: also, many packages don't consider cross-compiling as an option, so you need to deal with it

text: a couple of packages notoriously hard/impossible to cross-compile are cmake (ironic, isn't it?) and HDF5.  we simply don't do it

elements.text: a couple of packages notoriously hard/impossible to cross-compile are cmake (ironic, isn't it?) and HDF5.  we simply don't do it

text: I have no idea if it's possible to cross-compile gnuplot, but I see there are hurdles in front of us.  if you want to go ahead, you need to understand them and figure out a good solution

elements.text: I have no idea if it's possible to cross-compile gnuplot, but I see there are hurdles in front of us.  if you want to go ahead, you need to understand them and figure out a good solution
